IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: SPRINGSIDE AFFIRMS ITS CHOICE TO BE A SCHOOL FOR GIRLS AND YOUNG WOMEN. HERE STUDENTS DEVELOP THE POWER TO THINK, THE CONFIDENCE TO ACT, AND A SENSE OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR ONE ANOTHER. IN OUR DIVERSE COMMUNITY,STUDENTS LEARN TO HONOR THEIR DIFFERENCES AND TO SEEK COMMON GROUND SO THAT THEY WILL LIVE PRODUCTIVELY AND JUSTLY IN THE WORLD THEY INHABIT. ALL COLLEGE PREPARATORY SCHOOLS EXPECT THEIR STUDENTS TO EXCEL IN A RIGOROUS ACADEMIC PROGRAM. SPRINGSIDE ASKS MORE: THAT GIRLS DISCOVER HOW THEY LEARN, THAT THEY TAKE INTELLECTUAL DELIGHT IN THEIR EDUCATION, AND THAT THEY GAIN THE COURAGE AND INTEGRITY TO NEGOTIATE THE BREADTH OF THEIR COMPLEX FUTURES. IN EVERY WAY, SPRINGSIDE SCHOOL EDUCATES GIRLS AND YOUNG WOMEN TO DEVELOP THEIR CAPACITIES FOR LEADERSHIP IN THE 21ST CENTURY.
IRS990.MissionDescription: SPRINGSIDE AFFIRMS ITS CHOICE TO BE A SCHOOL FOR GIRLS AND YOUNG WOMEN. HERE STUDENTS DEVELOP THE POWER TO THINK, THE CONFIDENCE TO ACT, AND A SENSE OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR ONE ANOTHER. IN OUR DIVERSE COMMUNITY,STUDENTS LEARN TO HONOR THEIR DIFFERENCES AND TO SEEK COMMON GROUND SO THAT THEY WILL LIVE PRODUCTIVELY AND JUSTLY IN THE WORLD THEY INHABIT. ALL COLLEGE PREPARATORY SCHOOLS EXPECT THEIR STUDENTS TO EXCEL IN A RIGOROUS ACADEMIC PROGRAM. SPRINGSIDE ASKS MORE: THAT GIRLS DISCOVER HOW THEY LEARN, THAT THEY TAKE INTELLECTUAL DELIGHT IN THEIR EDUCATION, AND THAT THEY GAIN THE COURAGE AND INTEGRITY TO NEGOTIATE THE BREADTH OF THEIR COMPLEX FUTURES. IN EVERY WAY, SPRINGSIDE SCHOOL EDUCATES GIRLS AND YOUNG WOMEN TO DEVELOP THEIR CAPACITIES FOR LEADERSHIP IN THE 21ST CENTURY.
IRS990.Description: SPRINGSIDE, FOUNDED IN 1879, IS THE OLDEST GIRLS SCHOOL IN PHILADELPHIA AND PROVIDES INDEPENDENT EDUCATION IN GRADES PRE K TO 12 FOR 642 GIRLS FROM THE LOCAL AREA.EDUCATED 642 STUDENTS; RECEIVED RECOGNITION FOR THE ISITE PROGRAM FOR GIRLS & TECHNOLOGY; RECEIVED RECOGNITION FOR APPLIED PHYSICS PROGRAM AND SCIENCE PARTNERSHIPS.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: THE NET INCOME FROM ENDOWED FUNDS SUBJECT TO THE SCHOOL'S AUTHORIZED SPENDING POLICY WILL BE USED FOR FACULTY/STAFF SALARIES, FINANCIAL AID, FACULTY DEVELOPMENT, ATHLETICS, OTHER SCHOOL ACTIVITIES, AND GENERAL OPERATIONS OF THE SCHOOL BASED ON DONOR STIPULATIONS.

Form990ScheduleIPartIII.TypeOfGrant: SCHOLARSHIPS & FINANCIAL AID FOR VARIOUS STUDENTS

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Springside School subscribes to the NAIS Principles of Good Practice in Financial Aid Administration and has incorporated these into its school-wide financial aid policy. This policy 1) supports Springside's commitment to access and diversity; 2) enables Springside to enroll the best and brightest of its applicants regardless of need; 3) enables Springside to maintain and increase enrollment during a period of economic uncertainty and intense competition among schools. 1) A financial aid budget is set each year by the Trustees of Springside School using income from endowed funds and operating revenue. In setting the budget, the Board considers the level of need already existing in the school based on the previous year's allocations, as well as proposed tuition increases. 2) Springside strives through its publications and face-to-face contacts to publicize and explain its financial aid program and to disclose all information pertaining to the cost of a Springside education. 3) Allocation of financial aid funds is carried out by a Committee of Admission Officers and the Director of Finance and Operations; files are maintained by the Admissions Assistant. 4) Springside School does not discriminate in its financial aid allocations on the basis of race, color, religion or national origin; Springside does not use financial need as a consideration in determining a student's eligibility for admission; Springside uses a uniform methodology to assess annually, in a consistent and equitable manner, each family's ability to pay for education. a) Springside recognizes that primary responsibility for financing a student's education rests with the family, and that the family will have sought funds from all sources including employment, relatives, assets, and the Ellis Foundation (if eligible) in addition to seeking aid from Springside. b) Assessment of need is determined by the School and Student Service for Financial Aid (SSS) in Princeton, New Jersey, following the family's submission of a completed Parents' Financial Statement, supplemented by a copy of the most recent IRS 1040 form and a recent paystub to verify earnings. Assessment of need may require further verification. No financial aid award will exceed a family's demonstrated need. c) In awarding aid, the Committee takes into account the number, ages and schools of children, additional dependents, all sources of income including the student's own income, debts and unusual expenses, spending priorities, and whether a second working parent is contributing to family income where possible. d) In cases of divorce or separation, Springside requires a completed Parents' Financial Statement from the non-custodial parent, whether or not the non-custodial parent shares in the cost of education. If the student resides with a step-parent, Springside requires a PFS from the step-parent. 5) Springside strives to make awards as close to demonstrated need (based on the PFS) as possible, but also expects that each family will contribute an appropriate portion of tuition and fees. a) Exceptions to this are the specially endowed Neighborhood Scholarship Competition winners in grades six and up, whose aid may consist of full tuition, as long as there is demonstrated full need. 6) Awards are made on a one-year basis and require re-application every year. Families already in the school have priority over new families, as long as they meet the application deadline. Springside is committed to supporting a student through graduation at the same level of funding unless there is a change in financial circumstances. a) An award is contingent upon the family's meeting its financial obligation to Springside for the current year. b) Springside School does not set different standards of behavior or academic performance for financial aid recipients; high academic standards and exemplary citizenship are expected of all students. However, students on academic or disciplinary probation may lose their eligibility for Financial Aid, at the discretion of the Head of School. 7) Springside has a formal review procedure for families who wish to request additional funding, which requires a written appeal and a second meeting of the Financial Aid Committee. 8) Springside safeguards the confidentiality of all financial information supplied by a family, and shall refrain from and discourage others from making any public announcement of the amount of financial aid awarded to a student.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: Priscilla Sands received travel for her husband, housing and payment of club membership. Not included as taxable compensation.
Priscilla Sands received a deferred compensation payment of $250,414, becoming vested at the end of her present contract. All PAYMENTS were considered taxable compensation.

IssuerName.BusinessNameLine1: PHILADELPHIA AUTHORITY FOR INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT REVENUE BONDS

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 is provided to the voting members of Springside's Board of Trustees, the Head of School and the Director of Finance & Operations in electronic form. The Chair of the Board of Trustees, Head of School, Director of Finance & Operations and Members of the Governance Committee confirm that they reviewed the Form 990. A significant number of the other Trustees also confirm that they reviewed the Form 990.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board has a conflict of interest disclosure policy and requires all members of the board of trustees to fill out and return a conflict of interest statement annually.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Governance Committee of the Board of Trustees is responsible for overseeing the implementation and execution of all human resources policies, including compensation. The Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees reviews the compensation of the Head of School, reviews comparable compensation data and makes recommendations to the Governance Committee with respect to the Head of School's compensation. During the current year, the Compensation Committee and Governance Committee reviewed the compensation of the Head of School and, as part of the process, reviewed comparable compensation data for schools in Springside's peer group (including local schools and schools in the mid-Atlantic region). The Governance Committee made determinations based on this review.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19

Form990ScheduleRPartII.PrimaryActivities: FINANCIALLY SUPPORT EDUCATION FOR THE BENEFIT OF SPRINGSIDE & CHA
